article.headline: Five Huskies score in double figures
article.linkText: UConn bounces back, beats West Virginia
article.story:
MORGANTOWN, W.Va. (AP) -- No. 4 Connecticut wasn't about to
squander another big lead.

UConn took out the frustrations of having its 69-game home
winning streak snapped by beating West Virginia 82-57 Wednesday
night in the Huskies' Big East opener.

Following its one-point loss to Duke on Saturday, UConn dropped
from the No. 1 spot it had held for 15 consecutive polls dating to
last season.

In that game, UConn squandered a 20-point lead in the first
half, but gave West Virginia no chance to saddle it with
consecutive losses for the first time in 11 years.

"One of the problems that we have at Connecticut is we don't
know what to do with a loss," coach Geno Auriemma said. "We don't
know if we should remember it or forget it because it's happened
twice in the last three years."

Diana Taurasi chose to remember the Duke loss by making an early
statement against West Virginia. Taurasi scored all 14 of her
points in the first half to lead five UConn players in double
figures.

"Whenever you lose a game like that, you don't just drop it,"
she said. "We wanted to come out with a little chip on our
shoulder. When you lose a game of that magnitude, something's taken
away from you. You try to get it back little by little.

"Today we started really well."

Jessica Moore and Barbara Turner each added 12 points, Ashley
Battle scored 11 and Ann Strother had 10 for UConn (10-1), which
extend its conference regular-season winning streak to 44 games.

Yolanda Paige scored 14 points, Meg Bulger had 13 and Sherell
Sowho added 11 for West Virginia (9-4, 1-1), which lost to UConn
for the 13th straight time.

Kate Bulger, West Virginia's leading scorer at 16 points per
game, was held to 8 points on 3-of-15 shooting.

UConn's 33rd consecutive road win came against a team accustomed
to one-sided beatings from the Huskies. In their last six meetings,
the Huskies' average margin of victory has been 41 points.

West Virginia wore down quickly, using just eight players
because of injuries and two early-season defections.

The Mountaineers were plagued by foul trouble, failed to chase
down loose balls and couldn't keep up with UConn players cutting
inside for easy layups.

"We didn't have the answer off the bench. We don't have the
answer," said West Virginia coach Mike Carey. "It's going to be
the same thing all year. We're going to get pounded and pounded
inside."

UConn trailed 10-6 before taking control with first-half runs of
9-0 and 12-0. The Huskies shot 63 percent in the first half and 54
percent for the game.

Taurasi was held scoreless for the first eight minutes before
finishing the first half strong. She threw a laser pass to Turner
for a layup and hit a 3-pointer just before the buzzer for a 39-20
lead.

"You would think she had 40 points out there. She creates so
much for her team," Kate Bulger said. "We focused so much on her.
She knows how to pass, take it to the hoop. It's very hard to stop
her."

The Mountaineers' 20 first-half points were a season low.

West Virginia, outrebounded 44-31, hasn't beaten a ranked team
since the 1991-92 season.

Ten players scored for UConn, which led by as many as 37 points
in the second half.

"It was a step toward getting back to ourselves," Turner said.
"I think it was a new start."
